review_blob: Rich creamy mouth-feel that is full of dark coffee flavors with a slight bourbon undertone. The richness seems to fade off a bit faster than some other stouts with the richness on initial taste make up for the finish. There is a slight alcohol warming effect when you swallow the beer, but overall it is a great drinking beer that adds much needed complexity to the standard offering.

Aroma is full of citra aroma and a certain dankness that hits the nostrils. The appearance is a wonderful golden/orange color that has a small head that linger for a short time then goes away leaving lacing on top of the beer and on the glass. The taste is not quite as good as the aroma and appearance. My first thought is that in order to reach this alcohol content they left some hops in the fermenter for too long and it gives off a grassy note that is not very flattering for a beer with citra in it. It is a good beer but the off notes in the finish keep it from being a favorite. I actually prefer hoptologist from them to this beer.

Beer pours with a nice white head above a golden colored liquid that has a tinge of reddish when it is not being held up to the light. Aroma is too light for my taste but a funky dank smell is somewhat apparent. Taste is not very complex but is instead balanced with alcohol and some decent malts. I think if the alcohol contributed more flavor it might actually balance this beer out more. The hops seem a bit "Mono-hopmatic". Overall it is a decent beer but with regards to he other triple ipas I have had this one simply does not hold a candle.
beer_name: Knee Deep Hop Shortage Triple IPA

review_blob: Solid imperial stout that is begging t be aged in a barrel. Thick mouthfeel with a mocha head that leaves great lacing on the glass. Taste full of coffee and bitterness that hides itself dark cocoa. Great beer

Pours a very pale yellow color with a nice white head that leaves plenty of lacing in the glass. The aroma is probably this beers strongest attribute with a citrusy hop smell coming through cleanly. The taste is a bit light but that does make it very easy to drink. Overall this beer is not anything amazing but it is a decent example of a fresh hop ale.

2012 release of bourbon barrel-aged speedway stout. Aroma is thick with bourbon notes followed by a dark coffee and chocolate richness. The appearance is as dark as beers come with a thick mocha head that retreated much more slowly than expected for a 12% stout. The taste is very complex. Vanilla is a strong flavor but far and away the bourbon and coffee flavors are the centerpiece of the beer. Overall I love this beer. Bring friends to share a bottle with if you manage to get your hands on a bottle. It is a rich, thick beer that is best enjoyed slowly as it warms.
beer_name: AleSmith Speedway Stout - Bourbon Barrel Aged

review_blob: Another great beer from their anniversary series. This beer builds on the complexities that you have experienced in the previous releases. This beer is very complex but oddly drinkable Easily one of the best beers I have had

Aroma: The aroma of this beer is full of vanilla bean with the smoked porter coming through at the end.

Appearance: The appearance of this beer is very similar if not exactly the same as their regular porter.

Taste: I am honestly not a big fan of the way the vanilla flavor came through in this beer. To me it is a bit overpowering and does more to mask than compliment the other components.

Overall: Decent beer, I prefer the standard version

Great Beer. I had high expectations for this beer and it met or exceeded all of them easily. It is a very well balanced brew that has the nice bitter noted that are synonymous with the Ruination brand.
Wonderful beer. The hops are very clean and powerful with the malt in the finish helping take the edge off of the hops. Delicious beer

Aroma is very complex with all the hops and malts. Appearance is very dark, almost stout-esque. Taste is very nice. It has a very smooth mouth-feel. It has a great drinkability for a beer with such a high abv.

This is a decent beer. Based on the deScription I had very high hopes. It fell somewhat short of my expectations. A wood aged Double IPA should simply have more complexity and a somewhat smoother mouthfeel. This seems to have lost some of the floral notes that are normally present in the base beer.
beer_name: Great Divide Anniversary Wood Aged Double IPA

review_blob: Great imperial stout. This beer has very strong notes of chocolate and coffee that offset the high alcohol content. This is a sipping beer that really comes into its own when enjoyed slowly because as the beer warms up the chocolate and coffee notes really jump out at you.
Sampled on Draft (Nitro). This was a very nice surprise with the alcohol well hidden. It really seems like a session beer until you have had a pint. Worth a try if it is available in your area.

Release #16 8.9% ABV. Sampled from 22oz bomber. Appearance is very typical for a DIPA with a nice white head that fades away and leaves a little ring around the top of the beer. The aroma is soft pine note resins and sweet fruit notes. The taste follows the aroma very nicely and has a very full mouthfeel. Overall this is a great beer.

Very solid IPA. They did a nice job balancing the aspects of both of the individual beers. The maple syrup aspect does come through and it adds a certain "special" flavor to the beer. I seem to get more of the 60 minute on the initial taste and then later in the middle and finish I get some more of the complexities that are associated with the 90 Minute IPA

Appearance: this beers pour a deep dark black color with a fluffy cream/mocha colored head. Aroma: The aroma gives no indications that this beer is not just a standard DIPA or IPA. It is full of citrus and fruity notes. The taste shows some more of the black ipa characteristics with a bit darker malts coming through in the finish. Overall i enjoy this beer but it is not a game changer.
beer_name: Firestone Walker Wookey Jack Black Rye IPA

review_blob: I was skeptical when I heard this beer would be a nice balance between Dales Pale Ale and Gubna just simply based on how light Dales Pale Ale is.  They nailed it. the mouthfeel is very similar to Gubna but the taste and body are light like Dales Pale ale. Wonderful beer.
beer_name: Oskar Blues Deviant Dales India Pale Ale

review_blob: Not very impressed with this beer. The sour notes are very nice but it lacks the carbonation that it needs. The flavors are all very nice but it comes through a bit too :thick" for a beer of this style. I guess I am being harsh based on some of their other amazing sour/wild ales.
beer_name: The Bruery Vitis Series: Oui Oui

review_blob: Interesting beer. The flavors are very strong and come through much more vibrantly than I expected. Aroma is amazing. The coconut taste that come though is a bit strong for my palate but it is still an enjoyable sipper.

Appearance: Pours a golden/yellow color with a nice white head. Aroma: Full of hops with a nice sweet malt aroma in the background. Taste: Full of bitter and sweet hop notes that is followed by a very sweet malt backbone. One of my go to beers.

Appearance: Pours an oily, thick, pitch black color that has a mocha colored head that fades away quickly. Aroma: Full of bourbon notes that have both dark chocolate and coffee notes that compliment the barrel. The taste is very similar to the aroma only more vanilla notes come to the surface. Amazing beer

I picked up this beer with high expectations coming from the fact they brew Citra. This beer did not disappoint. The flavor is full of juicy hop notes that is very smooth and goes down nicely. I still prefer Citra but this beer really proves that Kern River can hang with the best of them when it comes to DIPAs

Bottle from the Bruery Provisions. Pours a golden/yellow color with a slight orange hue. Pours with little to no head. The aroma is very acidic with notes or apricot coming through. The taste is very similar to the smell however the apricot flavor comes through with much more clarity in conjunction with the sour notes. I find this to be a very refreshing beer.
UPDATED: MAR 15, 2012
beer_name: Bruery Terreux Sour in the Rye

review_blob: Wonderful smooth drinking stout. Drinks like an irish dry stout with a ton of flavor. I enjoy this style of stout when in he mood for something that coats the mouth yet doesnt knock you on you knees with alcohol

A nice well balanced beer. The flavor was a bit underwhelming compared to their other offerings. nice orange zest qualities lend a certain juiciness to the beer while the coriander simply brings the honey and orange flavors together. decent beer, not great

Aroma is full of sweet maple syrup and bourbon notes that seem to get more syrupy as the beer warms. The appearance is amazing it ruby red color that has some brown in it. The taste is pretty spectacular also. It starts off with the flavor of curmudgeon on the tongue but the middle of the mouth is wear much more complexity from the barrel aging come in. The finish has a bit of alcohol on the tongue yet it is very well hidden for an 11.9% abv beer. Overall this beer is wonderful.

The aroma is full of bourbon notes yet the velvet Merlins traditional coffee notes still come through in abundance. The appearance is typical of a stout. Taste is what I believe velvet Merlin should taste like in the first place. It is a wonderful beer and it was a please meeting mr Firestone. Velvet merkin should be tasted when you find it available

Aroma is full of white pepper with some light citrus and sour notes. The appearance is a golden color with a tint of blood orange in the mixture. The taste is simply amazing. It has great carbonation. The white pepper or yeast notes really set this Gueuze apart from the rest. This is probably the best beer that uses wild fermentation that I have ever had

Got this as a little gift from a trade. Pours a golden color with hints of orange when held up to the light and a nice white head that faded a bit faster than I anticipated for such a low abv beer. The aroma is that of a very nicely made pale ale. With a bit of grassy hop notes and a nice malt backbone coming through. The taste is very similar to the aroma. It is more of a pale ale due to the lack of overwhelming hop notes. That being said it is a pretty decent beer, although I wont go out and purchase it.
beer_name: Golden Road Point the Way IPA

review_blob: Aroma is full of hops and grain. The appearance is a dark ruby red color that poured with a large fluffy white head that is sticking around longer than I anticipated. The taste is a ton of hops up front that is then balanced by that cereal/grain flavor that must come from the use of buckwheat. This is a hotter beer I can taste the alcohol on the finish. Overall this is a great beer and I enjoy it

Aroma is full of bourbon notes with coffee and bitter chocolate filling in. he appearance is a pitch black color and it is very viscous. It pours with a nice mocha colored head that fades to a thin lacing across the top. Tastes is well in line with the other Eclipses that I have had, and the only difference is obviously the barrel it was aged in. This has a little more of the flavor from the barrel than say the brandy barrel. ( I Prefer the Brandy barrel to this.) This is an amazing beer and I hope to go to the release next year so I can secure some more bottles of the small batch Eclipse beer.
beer_name: FiftyFifty Imperial Eclipse Stout - Four Roses Single Barrel

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob: Aroma is full of bourbon and brandy notes that intertwine and really make the boozy nature of this beer apparent. The appearance of this beer is a deep dark brown color that is almost black but not. It pours with a brown/mocha colored head that fades away quickly. The taste is really very interesting. You can taste the two beers individually in each sip. When you take a sip you first are blasted with the brandy barrel-aged Angels share which is quickly soothed by the smooth texture of the bourbon barrel-aged serpent stout. It is a wonderfully complex beer that even at the 12.5% ABV makes me wonder if that is simply what the blend is before going into the barrel together.

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob: Tasted at the release event @ The Lost Abbey. Pours a dark red color that leaves some bubbles along the top but not so much that I would consider it a head. The aroma is full of Cabernet grapes and a slight oak notes that is finished off with the brett. The taste is interesting, but in a good way. My first sip didnt really unveil anything very sour, but as I continued to sip the character began to fill my tongue and the juicy cabernet flavors with the fine carbonation that seemed to fade away with the finish. The finish is where the majority of the brett flavor is hitting your palate. Honestly this beer tasted like a toned down version of Framboise de Amorosa with Cabernet grapes instead of raspberries. It is a good beer, I look forward to track 2
beer_name: Lost Abbey Box Set: Track #1 (Runnin with the Devil)

review_blob: Aroma is more subtle than I had expected. It has a very sweet honey like hop aroma that doesnt really show the depth of flavor that is soon to come. The appearance is very typical DIPA with this beer pouring with a white head that only lingers for a short time. Taste is really this beer strong point. It is very well balanced with the sweet malts somehow creating a balanced taste that begs for you to drink more. Great beer.
UPDATED: APR 9, 2012
UPDATED: JAN 22, 2012

Aroma is full of hop notes that have a more resinous quality combined with some tropical fruity notes. The appearance is exactly what it says on the bottle. It pours with a deep ruby/brown color when help up to the light. The taste is very nice, it only has a slight malt flavor that comes through as a roasted malt or a darker malt, but it is in no way the prominent flavor. The big star in this beer is the generous usage of hops in the beer. I can taste Citra or Galaxy for sure. Great beer, however; I enjoy Heady Topper from the alchemist more
beer_name: Stone / The Alchemist / Ninkasi More Brown than Black IPA

review_blob: The aroma is lighter than I expected I get light stone fruit notes and some slight hop resin but other than that it is a bit light on the aromatics. The appearance is a deep golden color with hints of red on the edges of teh glass. The taste is a bit more complex than the aroma. On the tip of the tongue the hop bitterness slides over lightly with the carbonation which is a bit heavy before revealing soft fruity flavors. The finish is full of bitterness and is very refreshing to me to find a beer that has the balance of the bitterness in the finish as opposed to all of the beers that are so hop forward.

After trying their Hurricane Deck DIPA, I was happy to see this beer in the cooler. This beer is relatively pricey for what it is, but how often do you get the opportunity of trying the first anniversary batch of beer from a small upcoming brewery. The aroma of this beer is very light with the majority of the aroma seeming to come from darker chocolate malts and some hops that manage to sneak the the curtain of darkness. The appearance is black with no light coming through with a head that is between off-white and mocha. The taste is really where this beer shines. On the tip of the tongue I get flavors of coffee, chocolate, and hops that all co-mingle to create a very nice, balanced mouthfeel. Great beer. I will probably go snag another even though it was priced at $20 at my local store.
Good example of this style of beer. Nothing really to write home about, but it is a nice well rounded session beer if you like the english style yeast flavor
UPDATED: JAN 6, 2012

Appearance is a golden/orange/light amber color. It pours wit a generous head that goes away somewhat quickly and leaves lacing on the glass. The taste is very well balanced. I find the hops a bit perplexing, because they are very prominent, yet the taste is not as aggressive as I feel a high quality DIPA should be
beer_name: Figueroa Mountain Hurricane Deck Double IPA

review_blob: Bottle (1Pint) pours a nice deep orange and golden color. Head is a white/off-white color. The  aroma is full of hop resin character. The taste is very similar. This is not a stunning beer, but it is a very drinkable and enjoyable beer.
UPDATED: DEC 25, 2011
beer_name: FiftyFifty Imperial Eclipse Stout - Elijah Craig 20 Year Barrel

review_blob: Good beer overall. It is interesting to taste this and then Double Jack. It really shows where all of the flavors and character are coming from.

Appearance is a deep golden color that poured with a huge fluffy white/off-white head. Aroma is full of the lemon zest and Lemon juice that are in the deScription. The hops are balanced very well with the lemon flavor. I find the lemon to be slightly too forward however it is very refreshing. Decent beer, not the best, but it is a well done Imperial IPA.
beer_name: Dogfish Head Hellhound On My Ale

review_blob: Wow....very interesting beer. Aroma is full of scotch notes. It is actually hard to get past the alcohol on the nose but it is easy to smell all of the roasted malts. The appearance is a brown/red color that leaves huge alcohol legs on the glass. Taste is very interesting. I was actually surprised that there is some carbonation in this beer. The taste is full of roasted malt notes with some nice raisin flavors coming through. Has a very Sherry like mouthfeel. The aftertaste is a bit tough on the palate, but for a beer of this size (32%) it sips well, albeit slowly.

Tasted both on draft and in a bottle on another date. I really enjoy this beer. I find the bitterness this beer has to be very pleasing to my palate. It is not overwhelming,yet at the same time it is very prominent on the tongue. It is not the greatest beer, but it is a solid session pale ale that is even better on draft.
beer_name: Great Divide Fresh Hop Pale Ale
